awd_titl_txt: Asymmetric Formal [4+1]-Cycloadditions for the Stereoselective Assembly of Quaternary Stereogenic Centers
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division supports the project by Professor Brandon L. Ashfeld. Professor Ashfeld is a faculty member in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at the University of Notre Dame, and is developing new synthetic methods that enable construction of functionalized heterocyclic and carbocyclic frameworks that contain very difficult to synthesize tetrasubstituted carbons. Cyclic systems that contain tetrasubstituted (or quaternary) carbons are found in a great number of molecules used in biological and materials science settings. Yet in spite of their importance, these ring systems remain difficult to synthesize, especially if they need to be constructed as a single "right-handed" or left-handed" mirror image in order to control molecular interactions with a biological system. To address this issue, Professor Ashfeld and his students are developing new methods for constructing both the hetero- and carbocyclic systems and the highly hindered quaternary carbons they contain. These methods take advantage of a transition metal catalyzed formal [4+1]-cycloaddition between a single carbon unit and a polarized four atom substrate. The catalyst used is chiral so that the reaction affords predominately one mirror image of the product. The project outcomes are broadly impacting the disciplines of synthetic and physical organic, organometallic, medicinal, and materials chemistry both in terms of the methods developed and the products generated. The scientific goals of the project integrate seamlessly with the education/outreach pursuits through the implementation of a target-based pedagogical philosophy toward STEM education at the secondary and post-secondary levels. These educational efforts are being complimented by Professor Ashfeld's contributions to the Upward Bound College Preparatory program in South Bend Indiana that serve to extend the program's reach beyond his labs to the larger community.

Quaternary stereogenic carbons and carbo- and heterocycles are pervasive architectures across numerous facets of academic and industrial chemical research. Despite the ubiquitous presence of 5-membered carbocycles and heterocycles in medicinal chemistry (e.g., CNS drugs, analgesics, antibiotics, etc.) and materials science (e.g., ionic liquids, high energy materials, etc.), the number of reliable methods for the assembly of highly substituted rings with flexible site-specific functionalization capabilities is relatively limited. Additionally, the synthesis of quaternary carbon centers is far from trivial, and to do so with control of absolute stereochemistry remains a significant obstacle in target-directed synthesis. Using the biologically active spirooxindole alkaloids as a motivating template for design, this project concurrently addresses these challenges through the development of a transition metal-catalyzed, formal [4+1]-cycloaddition for the fragment coupling of a diazo compound with a vinyl ketene to access cyclopentenones bearing a neighboring quaternary center, and vinyl isocyanates to construct the N-heterocyclic counterpart. By employing a well-defined chiral ligand-metal complex, assembly of the quaternary ring stereogenic carbon in a stereocontrolled fashion while acting as a point of spiro-attachment en route to numerous oxindole alkaloids, is tenable. Due to the chemoselective nature of the transition metal catalyst and relatively mild reaction conditions, this retrosynthetic disconnect is broadly applicable to a diverse array of synthetic targets. Completion of this study will ultimately lead to improved synthetic efficiency toward these important molecular scaffolds, and lay the keystone for long term significance in stereoselective quaternary carbon and carbo/heterocycle formation. The educational plan will integrate our findings in the training of graduate students in their approach toward synthesis, and the introduction of undergraduates to synthetic methods in laboratory offerings. The incorporation of a target-based approach toward molecule construction, such as quaternary carbon and heterocycle synthesis with tangible applications (i.e. pharmacophores), rather than the traditional reaction-centered lab design prevalent today, is an immediate goal. Graduate and undergraduates alike will gain a better appreciation for reaction design, and the discovery of new chemical reactivity, if their focus is on a series of specified target functionalities that are translational in nature.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

por.por_cntn:
The research outcomes that were generated from the National Science Foundation funded project CHE 1665440 related directly to the development of new methods and synthetic strategies in organic chemistry to more efficiently and cost effectively construct complex molecular scaffolds that are relevant to current and future needs in the pharmaceutical industry and materials science. The stereoselective construction of quaternary stereogenic carbons and the assembly of functionalized, highly substituted heterocyclic frameworks constitutes two main challenges in synthetic organic chemistry. This project sought to address both of these hurdles commonly encountered in complex molecule construction through the development of an asymmetric transition metal-catalyzed formal (4+1)-cycloaddition between a metallocarbene and a formal 1,4-dipole component, such as vinyl ketenes and vinyl isocyanates. During the funding period, we achieved 1) the convergent assembly of a 5-membered ring scaffold that had the inherent flexibility to allow access to both carbo- and N-heterocycles, 2) construction of a quaternary carbon with proximal functionality for subsequent manipulations, and 3) elucidation of mechanistic aspects from this work that allowed control of relative and absolute stereochemistry. Specifically, significant accomplishments included:

  1. The development of an alternative photochemical approach, and the foundation for a second metal-alkylidene method, for the assembly of vinyl ketenes that avoids the relatively inefficient and substrate limiting [2+2]-cycloaddition/reductive dehalogenation/electrocyclic ring opening sequence.
  2. Established the substrate scope of compatible vinyl ketenes, vinyl isocyanates, and diazo compounds in the Rh(II)-catalyzed (4+1)-cycloaddition.
  3. Design and development of a catalytic enantioselective, (4+1)-cycloaddition to control stereochemistry at the newly formed quaternary center.
  4. Elucidated key mechanistic aspects of the transition metal-catalyzed (4+1)-cycloaddition employing diazo compounds with vinyl ketenes and vinyl isocyanates.
  5. Determined the potential for sulfonyl hydrazones and triazoles as starting C1 synthons for the in situ generation of diazo compounds in our newly developed, RhII-catalyzed (4+1)-cycloaddition.
  6. Provided the foundation for further development of a (4+1)-cycloaddition employing an in situ generated Cu-allenylidene as a replacement for the vinyl ketene and vinyl isocyanate components.
  7. Successfully applied our (4+1)-cycloaddition technology to the convergent and streamlined construction of various heterocyclic frameworks of translational significance, including bis-spirooxindoles, imidazolones, and dihydropyrrolones. 
  8. Made strides toward the redesign of the commonly held pedagogical philosophy behind undergraduate laboratory instruction by emphasizing target analysis and retrosynthesis rather than the more common transformation-based approach. 

The findings that resulted from this funded project were disseminated in over 10 publications published in reputable, peer reviewed journals recognized internationally as leaders in their respective areas, provided the framework for subsequent studies based on synthetic methods development and target-directed synthesis. Additionally, numerous conference presentations and departmental seminars at industrial and academic institutions by the PI, graduate students, and undergraduates were made possible by this work, and used to the effectively communicate the results to scientific and broader audiences. The personnel outcomes associated with this award include four doctoral theses, and enabled 11 undergraduates at the University of Notre Dame to gain valuable research experience that will serve them throughout their future research and medical careers.

The broad educational outcomes and outreach objectives that were achieved throughout the execution of this project included community outreach to area high schools designed to encourage collegiate pursuits and progress toward the development of a synthetic target-based approach toward undergraduate laboratory instruction. The targeting of those structural motifs outlined in the research objectives integrated seamlessly with these education/outreach pursuits through the implementation of a target-based pedagogical philosophy toward STEM education at the secondary and post-secondary levels. Additionally, significant time and effort was spent toward the development of a platform for students in grades K-12 to become involved in the chemical disciplines thereby promoting these future pursuits for the next generation of scientists and engineers.


Last Modified: 01/09/2021
Modified by: Brandon Ashfeld
